Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: This unit of study explores the myths of ancient Greece and/or ancient Rome, the search for their meaning, and their contribution to both classical and modern culture.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: Myths are traditional narratives that examine ideas of central importance to a society. They were used by the Greeks and the Romans to explain the world, the foundation of institutions, aspects of daily life and the human condition. In the classical world, myth encompassed the nature of the gods, the deeds of heroes like Achilles and Theseus, and the epic voyages of Odysseus and Aeneas. Women such as Helen, Clytemnestra and Dido have endured in myths that contemplate love and war, the human and the monstrous. Students examine the nature and function of selected myths and consider the influence of the myths studied on modern culture.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: Students also explore the history of archaeology in the Mediterranean Basin, observing how the pioneers of archaeology sought to explain the possible historical basis of particular myths. They excavated sites such as Hisarlik (believed to be Troy), Knossos and Mycenae in search of the mythical heroes and their worlds. Students study archaeological sites connected to myths and consider the relationship between a myth and its archaeological record, such as site features and material culture. They critically assess whether there is a historical basis for the myth and draw evidence from the archaeological record to reach conclusions about the society that inhabited the site. Students engage with current debates about the ethics of archaeology and ownership of the past.

ContentDescription: In this area of study students examine the myths that underpin the cultures of ancient Greece and/or ancient Rome.

ContentDescription: Students investigate the key Greek and/or Roman gods, learning about their individual responsibilities and how they are represented in myths.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Gods, heroes and the legacy of myth

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Gods, heroes and the legacy of myth

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Gods, heroes and the legacy of myth

ContentDescription: Students explore narratives in Greek and/or Roman myths that explain the nature of gods and heroes, such as war narratives, quest narratives, and/or myths of the foundation of Greek or Roman cities.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Gods, heroes and the legacy of myth

ContentDescription: Students examine the ways in which classical works influence later ages by considering the impact of classical myths on modern culture, such as in film, literature or art; tracing the narrative pattern of the hero’s journey and observing similar patterns and tropes in modern works; or defining the traits of a Homeric or Virgilian hero and comparing these to modern characters who conform to, or depart from, classical heroic ideals, explaining why this might be the case.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Gods, heroes and the legacy of myth
ContentHeader: Gods, heroes and the legacy of myth
Elaboration: Students consider why myths of the classical world still resonate today, exploring where, how and why myths have been used and adapted.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
ContentDescription: In this area of study students examine the search for historical truth in myths that they have studied.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: These may be myths studied in Area of Study 1 and/or new myths selected for this area of study.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: There are numerous myths that have connections to archaeological sites, such as the Trojan War myth and its link to the sites of Troy and Mycenae; the Theseus and the Minotaur myth and its connection to the Minoan palace at Knossos.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: Also, the myths of Romulus and Remus, and Aeneas, and their roles in the foundation of Rome, can be linked to an examination of key sites in the city of Rome; and the worship of the hero Hercules can be connected to his mythical founding of various cities such as Herculaneum.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
ContentDescription: Students study the history of archaeological sites associated with myth.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: Students of Greek mythology could study the early development of archaeological methods in the work of Heinrich Schliemann and Arthur Evans, examining the triumphs, failures and controversies of these romantic figures and their excavations at Troy (Hisarlik), Mycenae and Knossos, and speculating about enduring questions such as whether the Trojan War really took place.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: Students of Roman mythology might examine the role of Mussolini in the archaeology of Rome, as much of what we see now is the result of campaigns to legitimise and glorify the Fascist regime.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
ContentDescription: Students study an archaeological site or sites, considering the historical basis of its associated myth.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: They study the site’s location and relevant era(s) of settlement, use and abandonment (if known); they examine its features, along with examples of the material culture from the site.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: They consider what the archaeological evidence reveals about the society (such as their daily life and customs, beliefs, values) and the concerns of the site’s inhabitants.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
ContentDescription: Students engage with past and current ethical issues associated with archaeology, such as how the reconstruction of archaeological sites influences our interpretation of them.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
Elaboration: They encounter the contested classical past, through topics such as repatriation and contentious ownership of artefacts, the impact of tourism on archaeological sites or the ethics of displaying human remains at those sites.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to explain how archaeology has informed our understanding of classical myths and society and identify ethical issues in archaeology.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Myths and archaeological practice
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: In this unit students examine classical society. They discover how mythic systems, ideas and beliefs, and classical works were integral to the fabric of classical culture. They use classical works, and the context in which they were created and disseminated, as a means of exploring religious, social, political or philosophical life in classical antiquity.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: Mythic systems and narratives provided the foundations of the ancient Greeks' and ancient Romans' beliefs and religious practices, and therefore their worldview. They permeated daily life; both representing and forming classical culture. In Area of Study 1 students explore where and how the original audience experienced these stories and the ways in which context informed their presentation. Students examine the use and place of myths in classical culture, considering how myths, ideas and beliefs were expressed in the religion and everyday life of Greeks and/or Romans, such as through festivals, religious rituals, cult practices, literature, art and architecture.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: In Area of Study 2 students analyse the ways in which creators of classical works convey ideas and beliefs in their works and how the works link to, and are influenced by, their socio-historical contexts. Students engage in close analysis of classical works, considering how ideas are expressed in classical works. They consider the influence on modern culture of a work or works they have studied.

ContentDescription: In this area of study students examine the use and representation of myths in everyday life.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
ContentHeader: Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
Elaboration: The practice of religion, which was underpinned by myth, informed many aspects of everyday life, social practices and politics in cultures that did not separate religion and state.

Elaboration: They investigate the physical and cultural context in which myths, ideas and beliefs were expressed to classical audiences, such as at sites associated with religious practices, in Greek and Roman drama, in art and in public and private spaces.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture

ContentDescription: Many classical works use myth as a basis for exploration of ideas and beliefs that are relevant to the contemporary context of the creator of the work.

ContentHeader: Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
Elaboration: They apply knowledge of a work’s context to their interpretation of the work.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
ContentHeader: Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
Elaboration: They consider how evidence about classical society and its beliefs and ideas is constructed by written works and material works.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
ContentHeader: Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
Elaboration: They examine features of a work’s artistic or literary form and examine the presentation of myth within the work.

ContentHeader: Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
Elaboration: They analyse the ideas and beliefs represented by myth and through the practice of mythic ritual, such as beliefs, values and attitudes.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture
ContentHeader: Myths, ideas and beliefs in classical culture

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students explore classical works, examining their ideas and how they are presented, and building a deeper understanding of the society in which the works were produced by developing interpretations based on evidence from classical works.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: Members of classical societies used different forms of works such as epic and lyric poetry, history, tragedy and comedy, philosophy, architecture and art to express ideas that were important to them.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: These works enabled classical writers and artists to respond to their socio-historical context and examine social and political life.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: Students analyse classical works and the socio-historical contexts in which they were produced.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: Socio-historical contexts might include relevant events and social, cultural, intellectual, political and performance contexts, as well as contexts of material culture, such as the work’s production, commissioning, intended use and audience.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: Students use this knowledge to aid their understanding of a work.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: Students explore what works reveal about the society that produced them.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: Analysis of classical works requires an understanding of the form or genre of the work, its creator and their intended purpose and audience, and the examination of the key ideas conveyed by the work and how these related to their socio-historical context.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: Students should be familiar with the conventions of the form or genre they are studying.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: Students also examine the techniques used by writers and artists to express their ideas.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: Examples of techniques for consideration can be found in Terms used in this study, pages 14–16.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: Students examine an example or examples of later culture that show the influence of a classical work or classical ideas they have studied in Unit 2.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: Elements of ancient Greek and ancient Roman culture have endured to the present day, exerting a powerful influence on art, architecture, literature, film, philosophy and science in Western society and beyond.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: Students consider how and why classical works and ideas have been used and the ideas or allusions they are intended to convey.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: Students might examine allusions to classical works they have studied in a work of poetry or other literature; or analyse an adaptation of a work they have studied.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
Elaboration: They could evaluate representations of characters or works they have studied in a modern film or consider modern characters in film or literature that are similar to those they have studied.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the ways in which works present the key ideas of ancient Greece and/or Rome.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing classical cultures
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: In this unit students engage with two forms of cultural expression of the classical world: epic poetry and material culture. Students develop their breadth of classical interpretation by examining two vastly different mediums through which classical societies expressed ideas and understandings.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: They explore the worlds and heroes in the work of an epic poet of Greece or Rome and consider the values and ideas conveyed by this foundational form of expression. They then examine Greek or Roman material culture, exploring physical and visual media such as monuments, buildings or artworks.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: Material culture offers a distinctive window for understanding the classical world and its cultural norms, ideology, rituals and daily life.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: Students consider these literary and material works within their socio-historical contexts, evaluating what they reveal about the ideas, attitudes and beliefs of the society that produced them, and further deepening their understanding of a classical society or classical societies.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: This area of study examines epic poetry, one of the most enduring ancient forms.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: Epics are long narrative poems typically set in the mythical world of gods and heroes.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: Epic poetry explores ideas of identity, heroism, legacy, the pathos of war, fate and the place of humans in the world.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: Through a study of epic poetry students come to understand how the Greeks or Romans grappled with these big ideas, and how they formed and expressed their identity and ideas through this genre.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: Epic poems reflect the concerns, beliefs and values of the socio-historical context in which they were produced.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: Understanding Homer’s socio-historical context entails situating the work in the context of its production in an oral culture in the Greek Archaic period.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: Students consider the broad social and political structures of early Archaic Greece and the changing nature of the Greek world as its city states transformed and expanded through colonisation.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: They consider what is known about the religion and customs of this period and the ideals and values that are conveyed by the Iliad.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: Much of Virgil’s life was lived against a backdrop of intense political unrest, culminating in the effective end of the Roman Republic.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: Students consider the Aeneid as both a celebration of Augustus’s achievements in restoring stability to Rome after civil war and a more subtle expression of misgivings about Roman imperialism and warnings against returning to conflict.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: Students examine details and features of the prescribed work.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: These reveal key ideas and values of the epic poet’s culture, as well as the work's broader significance to the whole prescribed work and its relationship to its socio-historical context.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: Students respond analytically, producing reasoned arguments that use evidence from the prescribed work.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: Through this close analysis of the work, they come to understand how epic poetry explored and shaped cultural identity.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: They examine and analyse the values of the Homeric or Virgilian worlds and the attributes and requirements of a hero.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: They see how their work presents ideas of fame, bravery and heroism, the pathos of war and the involvement of the gods in their fates.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: Students also study how the poem was composed, in either an oral context (in the case of Homer), or a literary context (in the case of Virgil), and key conventions and techniques of epic poetry.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: They need only consider techniques that can be seen in English translation and that reflect the original intention of the epic poet.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: These include descriptive techniques such as similes, epithets and formulae (repeated descriptive phrases), and narrative and structural techniques such as narrative prose and direct speech, including dramatic dialogue and speeches.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students study a work (in this case a ‘book’) of either Greek or Roman epic poetry.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
Elaboration: This is selected from the VCE Classical works list published annually in the VCAA Bulletin.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the key ideas and techniques in a prescribed work of epic poetry and explain its relationship to its socio-historical context.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The epic tradition
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: This area of study examines the material culture of ancient Greece or Rome.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Material culture is the visual and tangible remains of the culture.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Works of material culture provide insights into how a culture forms its identity, conveys its worldview and creates a sense of place and history.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Through studying material culture students come to understand how classical societies expressed their culture and ideas through physical and visual displays.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: Students closely analyse the prescribed work(s) and evaluate the importance of the subject to its form, such as how one feature of a building conveys the broader ideas of that building.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Students also examine the purpose of the work(s) and the ideas and themes expressed in it, and the methods and techniques used in the work’s creation.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: Identifying the features of a material work(s) entails understanding the work’s form, original use, method and time of production, and who (if known) built or made it.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Students understand the socio-historical context of the work(s) and the artist’s or producer’s purpose in creating it.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Students then analyse how the subject matter of the work(s) and the artistic, compositional and expressive techniques used to create it convey classical themes, ideas and beliefs.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: Students examine a range of techniques within material culture works, see pages 15-16.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Examples of works of material culture include buildings, sculptures and pictorial art.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: The study of a building or monument entails understanding the era in which it was produced, its patronage (if known), construction context and function.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Students learn about the form and original use of the building, its engineering and design, and the construction methods and materials used.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: They identify any explicit and implied messaging of the building and examine any iconography or symbolism within the features of the building.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: They also identify key ideas and cultural norms that are conveyed by the building and evaluate the artistic, compositional and expressive techniques the artist or architect has used to convey those ideas.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: The study of Greek or Roman sculpture involves examining a sculptural form, such as free-standing sculpture, portrait sculpture or relief sculpture (a wall-mounted sculpture on a monument or building).

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Students study a range of examples of the form from different periods in Greek or Roman history.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: For the purposes of this study, ‘pictorial art’ refers to forms of art that depict pictures or scenes, such as paintings, mosaics or imagery on vases.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: Students closely analyse the images on the artworks, examining their purpose, construction and (where relevant) the context in which they were used or displayed.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: The study of Romain mosaic considers the physical context in which the mosaic appeared, and the construction and placement methods used.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: The study of Roman paintings considers the physical context of the painting, the style of the painting, and the method used to create it.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: The study of the imagery on Greek vases involves understanding the original use or purpose of the imagery in relation to the shapes and styles of the vases, and the construction methods of the black-figure and red-figure techniques.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Students learn about the scenes represented on vases, mosaics and paintings and analyse the artistic, compositional and expressive techniques that are used to convey key ideas and cultural norms.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: They closely analyse individual works and consider their significance within a corpus of prescribed works.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: This might involve comparing similarities and differences in the presentation of ideas across several works and/or comparing different examples of the form.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: In this area of study, the work studied is prescribed in the VCE Classical works list published annually in the VCAA Bulletin.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
Elaboration: Each work or collection of works appears on the list for a minimum of two years and a maximum of four years.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the key ideas and techniques used in the production of the prescribed material work(s) and its relationship to its socio-historical context.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Material culture
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: In this unit students engage with the intellectual life of the classical world through a thematic cultural study of an overarching concern of classical culture and through analysis, evaluation and comparison of a range of different works. Students are exposed to a range of forms and genres of classical written and material works.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: In Area of Study 1, students analyse and evaluate the significance of a key concern of the classical world to understand how producers of works across forms and genres, time and/or societies engaged with similar ideas. Students analyse various short written works and material works and compare the ways these works of different forms and genres express similar concerns and ideas. Among the prescribed works for this area of study is a designated work from the pair of works they will study in Area of Study 2 (Work 1). In Area of Study 1, students focus on the expression of the classical concern within the works to develop and deepen their understanding of the broader socio-historical context in which the designated work was created.

Subject: Classical Studies
ContentDescription: In Area of Study 2 students engage in an in-depth comparative study of two prescribed works. They analyse and compare ways in which two classical authors use different genres and/or techniques to express ideas within their works and how different works represent similar ideas but may have different emphases and perspectives due to such variations as genre, socio-historical context and authorial intent.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: In this area of study students analyse a selection of prescribed materials and short written works that reflect a specified key concern of classical culture.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Prescribed materials will include short written texts, such as speeches, poems and short extracts from literary, historical, philosophical and other written works; and material works, such as free standing or relief sculptures, monuments, vases, coins and other artefacts.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Work 1 of the works to be studied in Area of Study 2 is included as one of the prescribed works in this cultural study.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: This provides students with an initial point of engagement with this work and its broader cultural context.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Through this cultural study students see that there are recurring concerns and ideas that preoccupied the people of the classical world, and that the expressions of these can be seen and analysed in works of different forms, genres and, in some cases, times.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: Students analyse works pertaining to one of the following concerns of classical culture and its associated prescribed materials and short works:

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: Classical identities

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: Power and authority

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: War and warfare

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: The ancient Greeks and Romans concerned themselves with issues of identity, questioning who they were and the nature of belonging.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Classicists examine how these people viewed themselves and others.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Classical identities can include masculine and feminine identities; the conceptions of barbarians and the ‘other’; the use of the past to form identity; the self-assured identity of 5th-century Athens; or the virtues to which ancient Romans aspired.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: The classical world features many significant, and sometimes dramatic, shifts in power.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Over time, the Greeks and Romans looked to various figures of authority, and pondered the nature of power and authority, both political and religious.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Classicists examine how the Greek and Roman people viewed the authority of religion and the power of the gods and fate; relationships between groups within society; ideas of good government or bad government; and representations of how power and authority are wielded through, for example, autocracy, oligarchy, democracy and tyranny.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: The classical world was often a world in conflict and war was an immediate concern for many people.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Classicists examine depictions of war and warfare in the classical world.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: These can include depictions of wars and battles, representations of how war was waged, and expressions of different attitudes to and perspectives on war and warfare.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Analysis of warfare includes different representations, both factual and mythical, of warriors and of conduct in war.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: Students evaluate representations of a classical concern through analysis and comparison of the prescribed works.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Among the prescribed works for this area of study is a designated Work 1 from the pair of works to be studied in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: Students analyse how a range of classical works reflect and exemplify a concern of the classical cultural context.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: They examine key features of the socio-historical context in which each work was produced, and the authorship of the work and its purpose, considering how socio-historical context, authorial intent and purpose shape meaning.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: Students analyse and compare key ideas related to the classical concern in works of different forms and genres, coming to see that there are overarching concerns in classical culture.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: They see evidence of continuity or change and form a deeper understanding of the classical world and the perspectives of its people.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
ContentDescription: A classical concern and related prescribed works are selected from the VCE Classical works list published annually in the VCAA Bulletin.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Classical concerns
Elaboration: Works will appear on the list for a minimum of two years and a maximum of four years.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: In this area of study students undertake an in-depth comparative study of two written classical works.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: As part of Area of Study 1, they examined how Work 1 of the pairing expressed an overarching concern of classical culture, providing them with an initial point of engagement with that work as a product of the time in which it was created.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Having developed an understanding of the socio-historical context of that work and a sense of its place within broader classical culture in its expression of a classical concern, in Area of Study 2 students engage more deeply with that work.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: They closely analyse its presentation of key ideas beyond the concern encountered in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: They compare it with a second work, designated Work 2.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Students compare the treatment of key ideas and techniques, and the features and contexts of these works.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: In their examination and comparison of the techniques used to present ideas in classical works, students focus on the likely intention of the classical authors and how their contemporary audience would have perceived the works, rather than the interpretation of modern audiences.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: The classical concern studied in Area of Study 1 should be considered where relevant, but analysis must focus on a wider range of key ideas presented in the works.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: Students examine and compare the techniques used to present ideas in classical works.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: The focus is on techniques that reflect the likely intention of the original author that remain evident in works in translation.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration:
Examples of techniques for consideration can be found in the Terms used in this study section on 
pages 14–16.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: The genre of a classical work shapes its meaning.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Classical authors use a wide range of techniques to convey ideas depending on the genre of the work.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Students become familiar with the conventions of the written genres studied and the techniques used with each.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Analysis and comparison of how the techniques of each genre add to the impact of the work lead to a deeper understanding of the choices that the classical author has made in presenting ideas.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: Each genre has distinguishing features.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Poetry, tragedy, comedy and satire are written in verse.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Philosophy and history are written in prose and may also use dialogue.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Epic and tragedy almost always focus on characters and events from myths and legends.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Greek comedy derides characters who are part of the author’s contemporary culture, while Roman comedy uses stock characters to mock different positions in society.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: History involves historical figures but treats the subject matter with more gravity than comedy or satire.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Historical narrative can have a particular logical and didactic quality that is different from what occurs in other genres; satire often has a sarcastic tone.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Some genres are intended to be viewed by a large and live audience, and others to be read by a learned audience.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Some are associated with specific techniques and conventions.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: For example, Greek tragedy and comedy have choruses, while epic uses repeated epithets and formulae that are typical of oral poetry that was only later written down.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: Students situate the works they study within their socio-historical contexts, linking them to the place and time in which they were produced.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: They form their understanding of socio-historical context by first situating the author, their purpose and their intended audiences.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: They also situate the works in the wider socio-historical setting of developments, events and features of the classical society in which they were produced.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: This knowledge of socio-historical context; that is, positioning the works in relation to the ideas and values of their specific time, place, and cultural conditions; supports students in deepening their understanding of classical works and the world in which they were produced.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: Paired written works are selected from the VCE Classical works list published annually in the VCAA Bulletin.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: Each pair of written works appears on the list for a minimum of two years and a maximum of four years.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to compare and evaluate the key ideas and the techniques in two classical works and evaluate the relationships between these works and their socio-historical contexts.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
ContentDescription: The examination will be set by a panel appointed by the VCAA.

Subject: Classical Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Classical comparisons
Elaboration: All the key knowledge and key skills that underpin the outcomes in Units 3 and 4 are examinable.
